Theorem 4.7. A compact topological space $K$ is metrizable if and only if $\mathbf{C}(K)$ is separable. 
Proof. Suppose that $C(K)$ is separable, and let $(f_{n})_{n\in\mathbb{N}}$ be a sequence in $C(K)$ such that $\{f_{n}:n\in\mathbb{N}\}$ is dense in $\mathrm{C}(K)$ .Define 
$$
\varPhi:K\to\Omega:=\prod_{n\in\mathbb{N}}\mathbb{C},\qquad\varPhi(x):=(f_{n}(x))_{n\in\mathbb{N}},
$$
where $\Omega$ carries the usual product topology.Then $\phi$ is continuous and injective, by Urysohn's lemma and the density assumption. The topology on $\varOmega$ is metrizable (see Appendix A.5). Since $K$ is compact, $\phi$ is a homeomorphism from $K$ onto $\varPhi(K)$ Consequently, $K$ is metrizable.

In this section we show how the compact space $K$ can be recovered if only the space $\mathrm{C}(K)$ is known (see Theorem 4.11 below). 
The main idea is readily formulated. Let $K$ be any compact topological space. To $x\in K$ we associate thefunctional 
$$
\delta_{x}:\mathbb{C}(K)\to\mathbb{C},\qquad\langle f,\delta_{x}\rangle:=f(x)\qquad(f\in\mathbb{C}(K))
$$
called theDirac or evaluationfunctional at $x\in K$ .Then $\delta_{x}\in\mathbb{C}(K)^{\prime}$ with $\left\|\delta_{x}\right\|=1$ . By Urysohn's lemma, $\mathbf{C}(K)$ separates the points of $K$ ,which means that the map 
$$
{\delta}:K\rightarrow\mathbb{C}(K)^{\prime},\qquadx\mapsto\delta_{x}
